headline.main: Nova Labs Funding Trail Leads to Offshore Accounts
headline.deck: Documents reveal systematic diversion of research grants through shell companies

content.text: The fluorescent lights of Nova Labs cast long shadows across empty workbenches as I reviewed the final batch of financial records. What started as a routine story about a promising biotech startup had become something far more troubling.
Three months of investigation have revealed a pattern of financial irregularities that raise serious questions about how Dr. James Chen managed his company's research funding.
The evidence began to accumulate in unexpected places.

content.caption: Bank transfer records showing wire transfers to Cayman Islands

content.text: I never authorized those transfers. Someone must have forged my signature.
content.attribution: Dr. James Chen, in written statement to NovaNews

content.text: Our analysis of Nova Labs' financial records revealed several concerning patterns:

items: $2.3 million in 'consulting fees' paid to shell companies
Research equipment purchases from non-existent vendors
Salary payments to employees who never existed

content.text: As this investigation continues, one thing is clear: the truth behind Nova Labs' finances remains partially hidden. But with each document we uncover, the picture becomes clearer.

pullQuotes.text: The money trail doesn't lie, even when everyone else does.

evidenceCards.headline: Wire Transfer Records
evidenceCards.summary: Bank records showing $500,000 transferred to offshore accounts over 6 months

evidenceCards.headline: Shell Company Registration
evidenceCards.summary: Corporate filings linking Nova Labs executives to offshore entities

entries.description: Wire transfer to Cayman Holdings LLC
